question: 2 (c)
sols_html:
The function we are trying to differentiate is the composition of four functions: three \(\tan x\) functions and an \(x^2\). Thus we will use the chain rule. This means taking the derivative of the outermost \(\tan x\) function and then replacing \(x\) with the rest of the function; then multiplying by the deriviative of the next \(\tan x\) and so on, until each part of the function has been differentiated.

(Recall that the derivative of \(\tan x\) is \(\sec^2 x\).)

\(f'(x) = \sec^2(\tan(\tan(x^2)))\cdot \sec^2(\tan(x^2)) \cdot \sec^2(x^2) \cdot 2x\).
sols_latex:
The function we are trying to differentiate is the composition of four
functions: three $\tan x$ functions and an $x^2$. Thus we will use the
chain rule. This means taking the derivative of the outermost $\tan x$
function and then replacing $x$ with the rest of the function; then
multiplying by the deriviative of the next $\tan x$ and so on, until
each part of the function has been differentiated.

(Recall that the derivative of $\tan x$ is $\sec^2 x$.)

$f'(x) = \sec^2(\tan(\tan(x^2)))\cdot \sec^2(\tan(x^2)) \cdot \sec^2(x^2) \cdot 2x$.
sols_raw:
The function we are trying to differentiate is the composition of four functions: three <math>\tan x</math> functions and an <math>x^2</math>.  Thus we will use the chain rule.  This means taking the derivative of the outermost <math>\tan x</math> function and then replacing <math>x</math> with the rest of the function; then multiplying by the deriviative of the next <math> \tan x</math> and so on, until each part of the function has been differentiated.  

(Recall that the derivative of <math>\tan x</math> is <math>\sec^2 x</math>.)

<math>f'(x) = \sec^2(\tan(\tan(x^2)))\cdot \sec^2(\tan(x^2)) \cdot \sec^2(x^2) \cdot 2x</math>.
statement_html:
Find the derivative of the following function.

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \tan(\tan(\tan(x^2)))\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
''Find the derivative of the following function.''

:<math>\displaystyle
f(x) = \tan(\tan(\tan(x^2)))
</math>
